text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text interrupted by a large historiated initial on the left; text block continues to the right of the initial. Wide margins on left and right filled with vertical acanthus and vine scrolls. A broad foliate flourish occupies the lower margin. The historiated initial dominates the visual hierarchy, drawing the eye before the surrounding text and marginalia.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata; professional book hand with uniform letterforms, expressive angularity, careful justification, red rubrics, and colored pen-flourished initials.

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for halos, diaper ground, and initial frame to signify divine presence. Ultramarine and vermilion alternate in initials and cloak, creating rhythmic emphasis. Leaf green anchors vine scrolls. Rose madder adds contrast in foliate ornament. Layered application of pigments with white lead highlights and minimal oxidation indicates high-quality materials and careful conservation.

features: Vertical alignment of figures within letter form
Frame of initial integrating figural and ornamental elements

decorative_elements: Acanthus leaf border scrolls in margins
Diapered gold and ultramarine background within initial
Large historiated initial with foliate extensions
Grotesque foliate roundels and interlaced spheres in lower margin
Pen-flourished red and blue minor initials

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen outlines in dark brown ink with variable weight; fine internal detailing in faces and drapery edges.
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color fields with subtle tonal modulation at fold edges and white lead highlights; minimal parallel hatching.
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without true linear perspective; depth suggested by overlapping figures and tiled floor pattern.

content_theme.scene_description:
Within the large historiated initial 'L', King David kneels at left, clad in an ultramarine-blue tunic edged with fine gold strokes and a vermilion cloak. His gold halo marks sanctity; hands are uplifted in prayer. He stands upon a red-tiled floor that conveys spatial grounding. Above him, set within a cloud nimbus at the apex of the initial, a bearded divine figure—Christ or Yahweh the Father—emerges, holding an open scroll inscribed with text. The background of the initial is a diaper pattern of burnished gold leaf set against a field of deep blue. Surrounding this central scene, the initial's red-and-green frame extends into elaborate foliate tendrils.

Secondary Elements: The side margins feature tall vine-scrolls of acanthus leaves in alternating blues, pinks, greens, connected by thin stems and occasional acorn motifs. The lower margin displays three interlaced foliate spheres with scrolling leaves in the same palette, flanked by punched gold dots. These decorative elements emphasize the divine–natural harmony and mirror the heavenly revelation. Halos, gold diaper, and the scroll symbolize divine authority and the transmission of Scripture. The composition centers on the act of prayer and reception of the Word, with all elements reinforcing this devotional focus.

religious: Divine figure in clouds holding scroll

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum with uniform thickness, smooth burnished surface and faint hair-follicle pattern. Regular quaternion gathering with cleanly trimmed edges.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal fading; slight flaking in vermilion areas; corners show minor cockling; overall stable with no major losses.
notable_physical_characteristics: Burnished gold leaf over raised gesso in halos and background
Regular plummet ruling lines under text
White lead highlights on foliate ornament

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual patron (lay or clerical) using it as a personal Psalter for private prayer

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This historiated opening of Psalm 119 originates from a high-quality late 14th- or early 15th-century Parisian Psalter, reflecting the period’s shift toward intensely personal devotion. Produced likely in a court or urban workshop, its use of ultramarine and vermilion – combined with burnished gold leaf and raised gesso – demonstrates access to expensive materials. The Gothic textura quadrata script and precise pen flourishing indicate a professional scriptorium environment. Iconographically, the depiction of King David kneeling in prayer before the divine figure emphasizes the human desire for direct scriptural engagement, characteristic of pre-Reformation devotional trends. The elaborate vine scroll margins and diapered backgrounds link this page to the International Gothic style, showing affinities with other luxury manuscripts such as the Psalter of Louis of Orléans. Compositionally, the hierarchical scale—divine figure above supplicant—reinforces theological priorities, while the integration of text and image within the initial fosters a seamless visual-textual encounter. The border’s naturalistic acanthus motifs echo contemporary advances in botanical rendering. Comparatively, the work shares technical achievements with the Boucicaut Master’s atelier, yet its floral ornamentation suggests local Parisian influences. Overall, this page exemplifies the confluence of art, devotion, and patronage on the eve of the Renaissance.
